content: I was just curious about something. I know that we are going to get a $400 a year tax credit, right? Well, that particular tax credit was granted to us and signed into law as part of the stimulus bill, right? Every bill has a dollar figure on it (cost of the bill), right? All bills that become law (and, have a dollar amount on them) are paid for through taxation, right? Ok, here is my question. If it was given to us through the stimulus bill, was the cost of the tax cuts added to the total cost of the stimulus bill (i.e. a dollar figure for that particular section)? Does anybody know what it is? Or, is it an actual change to the tax code and therefor did not add to the cost of the stimulus bill? And, yes. I do know that it temporarily changes the withholding table. But, that is not what I am asking. Did it actually add to the cost of the stimulus?
reply: I was just curious about something. I know that we are going to get a $400 a year tax credit, right? Well, that particular tax credit was granted to us and signed into law as part of the stimulus bill, right? Every bill has a dollar figure on it (cost of the bill), right? All bills that become law (and, have a dollar amount on them) are paid for through taxation, right? Ok, here is my question. If it was given to us through the stimulus bill, was the cost of the tax cuts added to the total cost of the stimulus bill (i.e. a dollar figure for that particular section)? Does anybody know what it is? Or, is it an actual change to the tax code and therefor did not add to the cost of the stimulus bill? And, yes. I do know that it temporarily changes the withholding table. But, that is not what I am asking. Did it actually add to the cost of the stimulus?
title: Tax credit question

content: Oops, found the answer. The "Making Work Pay" portion of the stimulus added $145 billion to the cost of the stimulus. So, I guess my next question would be: How in the heck is it a tax cut if we have to pay for the $145 billion that this "tax cut" costs through taxation? Am I missing something here?
reply: Oops, found the answer. The "Making Work Pay" portion of the stimulus added $145 billion to the cost of the stimulus. So, I guess my next question would be: How in the heck is it a tax cut if we have to pay for the $145 billion that this "tax cut" costs through taxation? Am I missing something here?
title: Tax credit question

content: 10tenths; If you go to the IRS website (this being a .gov link it should be legit), there is a link at the bottom where you can calculate how much your tax burden will be with the government giving you more of your money back now. http://ftp.irs.gov/individuals/article/0,,id=96196,00.html I calculated ours earlier today, and it said we would owe over $400 next year because we will not have enough taken out, so I asked my husband to change his W4, so that we can maybe break even. And no your not missing anything, yet, except that you may end up owing a large chuck of money to the government next year when you file your taxes..

content: 10tenths; quote: Wait a minute. So, you are saying that it is causing you to actually owe it right back to them at the end of the year? Is that what you are saying? That's how ours worked out, yes.. Go to the website, punch in your information, it might come out better for you.. For us, I'm a stay at home wife/mother, but they have changed the taxes at my husbands job and his retirement income, and because both are taxable it put us in a higher income bracket, so it is working out that we won't be paying enough in.. if I worked outside the home, we would end up owing even more..unless I also changed my deductions to zero.

content: The tax incentive can be taken early (the check) but you must show that you received it on your tax return. If for some reason, you did not receive it, you can claim that as well on your return. Either way, you still 'get' the incentive. The listing on the 1040 form is when you did NOT receive the payment. Many people interpret this as 'having to pay it back' directly. Their mistake. Much like those who earned a $7500 incentive if you bought a new home last year (like me). What it actually is, is a 15-year interest free loan, for which I will pay $500 back in taxes for the next 15 years. Was it worth it? Sure, I will be able to itemize and deduct my interest payments on teh house and garner far more than the standard deduction. Probably enough to cover that $500 per year payback. Besides, with an interest rate of 5.5%, the purchase was a no-brainer. Sullivan013
reply: The tax incentive can be taken early (the check) but you must show that you received it on your tax return. content: 3678131, I did and it gave me some crazy amount for a refund (like $1400 or something). I never get refunds because I try to keep it as close to 0 (give or take $500 either way) as possible. It is kind of hard for me to get an accurate answer due to the fact that I have multiple income and make different sums of money from week to week, month to month. It doesn't help that I only have withholding on one of those incomes. To keep myself close to zero I have a deferred annuity that I will throw money into to bring my taxes owed closer to 0 before I file at the end of the year. I am single and file 2 or 3 allowances depending on my month to month income. Like I said, it really is a pain due to how different my income is month to month. But, I will take your word for it. If anybody else makes the same income year to year wants to give it a try, I would love to hear the results.
reply: 3678131, I did and it gave me some crazy amount for a refund (like $1400 or something). I never get refunds because I try to keep it as close to 0 (give or take $500 either way) as possible. content: Either way, the main point is that it did cost $145 billion in the bill, when that bill became law it is paid for through tax revenue. So, we are paying it back one way or the other. esample, it doesn't matter whether it is permanent or not. If a bill passes and costs a specific amount of money, it is paid for through tax revenue. So, that $145 billion will get paid by the taxpayers. So, how is that a tax cut?
reply: Either way, the main point is that it did cost $145 billion in the bill, when that bill became law it is paid for through tax revenue. content: L0A1; quote: Cap and trade will add around 3000 - 4000.00 extra per year in Tax increases. For those that do not expect the Power companies to pass the tax down, which is ridiculus, then it's still $800.00 per household increase. My husband and I were talking about this earlier, how the 'extra' taxes will effect EVERY THING.. quote: According to the White Fence Index, the average home utility bill is $297 per month, which is about $3,600 per year. So a 50% increase would be $1,800 per year under the Obama proposal. This far exceeds a Heritage Foundation projection of $467 a year in higher utility bills under an earlier U.S. Senate energy tax plan. That less-aggressive plan, though, could have cost 500,000 to 1 million jobs, according to Heritage. Who knows how many jobs would be lost under Obama’s more burdensome plan? The lost jobs would become “gangrene jobs,” a counter to Obama’s claim to create new “green jobs.” The White House and Mr. Furman try to justify drastically higher energy costs by offsetting it with their plan to give 95% of American families a permanent $800 per year “Making Work Pay” tax credit. (42% of that “tax cut” would actually go to people who don’t pay any income tax.) But even with the $800 subsidy, the net loss is $1,000 per family per year. "http://www.humanevents.com/article.php?id=31137" And if you think about it, they want to go to electric cars..so who is the joke being played on?? "http://gas2.org/2009/03/19/president-obama-announces-24-billion-in-funding-for-electric-vehicles-and-plug-in-hybrids/"
quote: Cap and trade will add around 3000 - 4000.00 extra per year in Tax increases. For those that do not expect the Power companies to pass the tax down, which is ridiculus, then it's still $800.00 per household increase.

The lost jobs would become “gangrene jobs,” a counter to Obama’s claim to create new “green jobs.” The White House and Mr. Furman try to justify drastically higher energy costs by offsetting it with their plan to give 95% of American families a permanent $800 per year “Making Work Pay” tax credit.
